710983f.text:
Eighth Stroet,Astor Place and Lafayette Place showing the old buildirg of the Nercantile Library,or Clinton Nall,erected at tho junction of hhose Avenues. Tho Library was founded on November 9,I920 by clerks of merchants. In I82I it was locgted i1 ore room at 949 Fulton Street,with I50 members and 700 volumes. From this time it grew rapidly and in I830 a Clinton -Hall Association was formed for the purpose of erectirg. In I85d tho Association purchased the Astor Place Opera Pouse,remodeled it for a Library as shown in picture,later this was replacod, in IE9I hy the present building,with capacity for 475,000 weolumes.
Ref: King's Berdbook of New York.P.328.

ia on tho Friends Meeting House.

710980f-a.text: East 8th Street, at, adjoining and west of the N. W. corner of 4th Avenue, as seen from Astor Place (foreground) at Lafayette Street. The corner building mentioned (extreme right) bears No. 38 4th Avenue in the Perris, New York Insurance Map of 1854. Adjoining same is St. Ann's R. C. Church, with No's. 145, 143 and 141,.progressing westward to Broadway. Across the background appears the new A. T. Stewart Building, which today (1937) is the north unit of Wanamaker's. The south unit being raised on the area occupied as shown in this view, exclusive of No. 38 4th Avenue and adjacent. In 1879, a Jacob Aberle converted the church building into a variety theatre, known as the 8th Street Sheatre. About 1890, performances were given in Hebrew by native actors. It was called the Germania and German Theatre in 1897 and 1902 respectively. About i905 it formed a portion of the present site of the aforementioned department sbore.

719209f-a.title: Manhattan: Cooper Square (North) - [Astor Place.]
719209f-a.text:
52 to 34 Cooper Square, west side, south of Astor Place (center). Shown on the right is Cooper Institute a 7-story structure occupying the entire block west from Third Ave. (elevated line thereon) to Fourth Ave. and East 7th Street (north side of triangular park) north to Astor Place. In the background is the huge department store of John Wanamaker's (formerly Stewarts). Note the Cooper statue in the foreground on the approximate site where this great philantMopist sat daily and looked down the Bowery. It is the work of Augustus St. Gaudens, a graduate of
the Institute and was unvailed May 29, 1897.
About 1925.
Ewing Galloway.
NEG ~ 3320

710982f-a.text:
8th Street, at the intersection of Fourth Avenue, Astor Place, and the northern end of Lafayette Street. The car track in the foreground is on 8th Street; the street car is going west on Astor Place past Bible House, which however, has its own house numbers
instead of Astor Place house numbers.
Rible House was built in 1852 by the Ame ican Bible Society. In the background, on the west side of Fourth Avenue, may be seen the newer
of the John Wanamaker stores, built around 1905.
August 5, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

Fourth Avenue, north from E. 9th Street as fhotographed from the traffic island at 8th Street. At the left is the north building of John Wanamaker's Department store. This occupies the 9th to 105h Street frontage. 14th Street is in the background where the perspective is lost because of the bend at Union Square. The Central Savings Bank building fs at that point. Above same, and berely perceptible are the towers of the Metropolitan Life IWsurance Co. and the Empire State
buildings.
